topic.title: Using Oxygen XML Editor in a Web Browser - (Experimental)

body.p: The JetBrains Projector is a technology for rendering Swing applications over the network and it's thus an interesting way to run and access these apps remotely. Some of its usecases are listed here: .

As Oxygen XML Editor is a Swing Java-based application this blog post gives some steps about how Oxygen XML Editor could be accessed remotely and used from a web browser. Oxygen XML Editor running in the Safari web browser using JetBrains Projector

The following steps are needed to prepare an Oxygen XML Editor installation on the server side for running in a web browser:
Download an all platforms oxygen.tar.gz installation kit of Oxygen: and unpack it to an oxygen folder.
Download the Jetbrains projector installer and unzip it in the Oxygen installation folder, the folder path should be something like oxygen/projector-server-1.5.0.
Download the Jetbrains Java 11 runtime enviroment and unpack it to the oxygen/jbr folder.
Create a start-projector-oxygen.bat script in the oxygen installation folder so that it adds the JetBrains libraries to the classpath and runs the JetBrains server giving it as a parameter to name of the Oxygen main class to run with the contents:@echo off SET CP="%~dp0;%~dp0/classes;%~dp0/lib/oxygen-basic-utilities.jar;%~dp0/lib/oxygen.jar;%~dp0/projector-server-1.5.0/lib/*"
%~dp0\jbr\bin\java.exe %OXYGEN_JAVA_OPTIONS% -Dcom.oxygenxml.app.descriptor=ro.sync.exml.EditorFrameDescriptor -cp %CP% -Dorg.jetbrains.projector.server.classToLaunch=ro.sync.exml.Oxygen org.jetbrains.projector.server.ProjectorLauncher %*
Run the start-projector-oxygen.bat script which will by default start an HTTP server on port 8887.
Connect from the same computer to the localhost:8887 port or from another computer using a web browser.
You should be able to use Oxygen XML Editor in a web browser and have full access to the server side resources.
